p: Cauchemez et al. calculated the risk of microcephaly during ZIKV outbreak in French Polynesian outbreak (Sept, 2013, to July, 2015) through statistical data, mathematical models and serologic data ( 9). The authors has suggested that 95 out of 10,000 cases (1%) of neonates and fetuses whose mothers got ZIKV infection in their first trimesters had microcephaly, a prevalence that was around 50 times as high as the calculated baseline prevalence. Based on the findings of computed tomography (CT), 23 cases of microcephalic infants born to mothers showing ZIKV symptoms during first or second trimesters were discussed by authors ( 28). While another report presented 22% risk of microcephaly during first trimester. Similarly, a more recent cohort study has reported that prevalence of ocular and neurologic malformations were more commonly observed during the first trimester of ZIKV infected mothers (12.7%) as compared to second (3.6%) and third trimester (5.3%) ( P = 0.001) ( 29).
